citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility is currently not following their program of veterinary care’s (PVC’s) schedule for regularly scheduled visits to
the facility. The facility’s PVC states that the attending veterinarian (AV) will provide on-site evaluations quarterly. Per
facility representatives, the last on-site visit was performed in April 2024 by the previous AV. Although the facility has
discussed a potential visit with the current AV, no date has been set at the time of the inspection. Following the PVC’s is
critical to evaluate animal health and well-being, as well as to help identify any animal husbandry issues that may affect
the animals. Correct by meeting the program’s on-site evaluation frequency and resume regularly scheduled visits of the
AV to the premises.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One of the two pigs housed in the pig enclosure has long hooves with mild outward curving causing splaying and
abnormal positioning of the toes. Excessively overgrown hooves can result in abnormal weight distribution and eventually
lead to discomfort, pain, and lameness. Prompt diagnosis and treatment of overgrown hooves and claws is necessary to
maintain animal health.
Correct by August 30, 2024 by ensuring the overgrown hooves have been addressed.

A primary enclosure housing two adult Bengal-hybrid cats contains an unprotected electrical cord that is accessible to the
cats. This cord is used to power a working cat water fountain. Unprotected cords pose an injury risk, should the cats
damage them. All enclosures should be constructed and maintained so that they protect the cats from injury.
Correct by: August 12, 2023.

The facility is not maintaining housing for birds in good repair or protecting the birds from injury. The enclosure of the two
eclectus parrots shows chewed zinc-coated wire leaving sharp points and chewed stained-wood support beams leaving
sharp splinters. The budgie room containing 184 birds has several nesting boxes that are chewed, leaving sharp splinters,
and a hanging perch with an exposed screw. Primary enclosures must be constructed of suitable materials and
maintained so that they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds.
Correct by September 6, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility’s environmental enhancement plan (EEP) states that enrichment to promote foraging, object manipulation,
and sensory stimuli will be provided no less than twice weekly. The facility’s last documented enrichment log is dated the
week of June 3, 2024, and it does not document that enrichment was provided as required by the EEP. Birds have
complex needs which if unmet may cause stress, boredom, and the development of abnormal harmful behaviors. The
environmental enhancement program aims to create and maintain a structured plan to meet birds’ complex behavioral
needs. The facility must ensure that consistent implementation and documentation of the plan is performed to monitor that
the plan is meeting the psychological well-being and health of the birds.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
A moderate amount of mouse feces is on the floor along the walls in the office space that currently houses a golden
parakeet and two budgies. A mouse is observed running for cover when the door to the storeroom adjacent to the office
was opened. In another area of the facility, a room adjacent to the budgie room has a large amount of mouse feces along
the pallet storing several bags of animal bedding. A small amount of mouse feces is observed outside of the budgie
enclosure. Several fruit flies are swirling above the plates of produce in the macaw and golden parakeet cages.
Pests such as mice and flying insects can spread disease and contaminate food, surfaces, and animal housing areas. An
effective program for control of insects and rodents must be established and maintained to promote the health and
wellbeing of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Jennifer Walker, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
